title: Theory of Angular Momentum
section: 2 Rotations and Angular Momentum Commutation Relations
text:
2 Rotations and Angular Momentum Commutation Relations
In classical mechanics we cause rotation of a vector \(\vec{v}\) by applying a rotation matrix \(R\) such that \(\vec{v'}=R \vec{v}\) where \(\vec{v'}\) is the rotated vector. The rotation matrix is suppose to follow the following properties

\[R^{T}R = RR^{T} = I\]
\[\sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2 + v_z^2} = \sqrt{v_x'^2 + v_y'^2 + v_z'^2}\]

Now in 3D we can generate all the rotations possible using 3 matricies around x,y and z axis using \(R_x(\phi)\), \(R_y(\phi)\) and \(R_z(\phi)\). For very small angle \(\phi\), the above matricies allow the commutation relation as \([R_{x}(\epsilon),R_{y}(\epsilon)]= R_{z}(\epsilon^2)-I\)






NoteÂ 1: Exercise



Generalise the above commuation relation.


Now one of the important lessons of quantum mechanics is that we can rotate a physical system in \(\mathrm{R}^{3}\) then there should be a corresponding operator \(\mathcal{D}(R)\) such that it rotates the wavefunction in the hilbert space \(\mathcal{H}\) such that \(|\alpha\rangle_{R}=\mathcal{D}(R)|\alpha\rangle\). And the physics in the rotated frame is given by \(|\alpha\rangle_R\).






NoteÂ 2: Exercise



Show that \(\mathcal{D}(R)\) is an unitary operator.


Now let us consider a unitary operator which generates the rotation and let \(\vec{J} \cdot \hat{n}\) be the generator of the rotation where \(\vec{J} = \{\hat{J}_x, \hat{J}_y, \hat{J}_z\}\) and \(\hat{n}\) is a unit vector in the direction of the rotation axis. So we can write the \(\mathcal{D}(R) = e^{-i \vec{J} \cdot \hat{n} \theta}\). Now in the small angle approximation we have \(\mathcal{D}(R) = 1 - i \vec{J} \cdot \hat{n} \theta + \mathcal{O}(\theta^2)\)

title: Theory of Angular Momentum
text:
3 Finite Rotation in Quantum mechanics
We can re-write the rotation around an axis as compounding of multiple infinitesimal rotation around the axis as \[
\mathcal{D}_z(\phi) = \lim_{N \to \infty} \left(1 - i \hat{J}_z \frac{\phi}{N}\right)^N
\] which is \[
\mathcal{D}_z(\phi) = exp(-i \hat{J}_z \phi) = 1 - \frac{i \hat{J}_z \phi}{\hbar} - \frac{ \hat{J}_z^2 \phi^2}{2 \hbar^2} + \mathcal{O}(\phi^3)
\] Now let us try to figure-out the angular momentum algebra using the rotation operator. Now we assume that rotation operator have same group properties as the classical rotation matrices.

Identity: \(R \cdot I = I \cdot R = R\) \(\implies\) \(\mathcal{D}(R) \cdot I = I \cdot \mathcal{D}(R) = \mathcal{D}(R)\)
Closure: \(R_1 R_2 = R_3\) \(\implies\) \(\mathcal{D}(R_1) \mathcal{D}(R_2) = \mathcal{D}(R_3)\)
Inverses: \(R R^{-1} = R^{-1} R = I\) \(\implies\) \(\mathcal{D}(R) \mathcal{D}(R)^{-1} = \mathcal{D}(R)^{-1} \mathcal{D}(R) = I\)
Associativity: \(R_1 (R_2 R_3) = (R_1 R_2) R_3\) \(\implies\) \(\mathcal{D}(R_1) (\mathcal{D}(R_2) \mathcal{D}(R_3)) = (\mathcal{D}(R_1) \mathcal{D}(R_2)) \mathcal{D}(R_3)\)

Now using the commutation relation of classical rotaion matrix one can workout the commutation relation of the angular momentum operator.






NoteÂ 3: Exercise



Workout the commutation relation of angular momentum operator using rotation operator commutation relation, which follows from the fact that they have same group structure.


So one of the central results of this section is the angular momentum algebra given as \[
[\hat{J}_i,\hat{J}_j] = i \hbar \epsilon_{ijk} \hat{J}_k
\tag{1}\]
EquationÂ 1 shows that the angular momentum operators forms an non-abelian group, which is different from the translation as the generators \(p_{j}\) form an abelian group. Now in principle I only need EquationÂ 1 to give all the properties of angular momentum operator and hence rotation operators. But now the question is how the expectation values change with the rotation operator? Consider the expectation value \(\langle \hat{J}_x \rangle\), it is defined as \[
\langle \hat{J}_x \rangle = \langle \alpha_R | \hat{J}_x |\alpha_R\rangle = \langle \alpha |\mathcal{D}^{\dagger}_z \hat{J}_x \mathcal{D}_z|\alpha \rangle
\] Now the let us see how \(\hat{J}_x\) transform under the rotation around z-axis? \[
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{D}^{\dagger}_z \hat{J}_x \mathcal{D}_z = e^{-i\hat{J}_z\phi} \hat{J}_x e^{i\hat{J}_z\phi}
&= 1 + \left(\frac{i \phi}{\hbar}\right) [\hat{J}_z,\hat{J}_x] + \frac{1}{2!} \left(\frac{i \phi}{\hbar}\right)^2 [\hat{J}_z,[\hat{J}_z,\hat{J}_x]]+....\\
&= \hat{J}_x \cos(\phi) - \hat{J}_y \sin(\phi)
\end{aligned}
\] Now note that these operator transforms as a vector under rotation.






NoteÂ 4: Exercise



Show explicitly that angular momemtum operators along different axis transform as a vector under rotation.

title: Purcell Filter
text:
In circuit QED, the qubit is coupled to a readout resonator which is in turn coupled to a transmission line. This coupling allows for interaction of the qubit with field around and sends away itâ€™s information to the measurement apparatus, FPGAs in our case. However, this coupling is dispersive in nature and lead to unwanted decay of qubit state via the resonator, known as Purcell decay. To mitigate this we use a Purcell filter, obviously. The system hamiltonian is given by \[
H = (\omega_r + \chi \sigma_z) a^\dagger a + \frac{\omega_q}{2}\sigma_z
\tag{1}\] where \(\chi = \frac{g^2}{\Delta}\) is the dispersive shift which is the amount by which the resonator frequency shifts depending on the qubit state. We exploit this shift to tell the qubit state. But the problem is the readout resonator decays into the transmission line with a rate \(\kappa_r\), this is essentially in some sense the rate at which information about the qubit state is gained. This decay also opens up a decay channel for the qubit via the resonator given as \(a \to a-\frac{g}{\Delta} \sigma_{-}\). This leads to an effective decay rate of the qubit given by \(\kappa (\frac{g}{\Delta})^2\).
Now the possible way out of this decay problem is:

Increase \(\Delta\): But this reduces \(\chi\) and hence the readout fidelity.
Decrease \(\kappa_r\): But this increases the readout time and hence reduces the measurement bandwidth.
Decrease \(g\): But this again reduces \(\chi\) and hence the readout fidelity.

Now another way forward is to somehow have different rates for resonator and qubit. This is where the Purcell filter comes in.

title: Purcell Filter
text:
2 Circuit Diagram and Hamiltonian










FigureÂ 1: Circuit Diagram of a qubit coupled to a readout resonator which is in turn coupled to a Purcell filter and then to the transmission line



Consider the hamiltonian of coupled-resonators and qubit system given by \[
\hat{H} = \omega_r a^\dagger a + \omega_f b^\dagger b + G^{*} a b^\dagger + G a^\dagger b + \omega_q \sigma_{+}\sigma_{-} + g(a \sigma_{+} + a^\dagger \sigma_{-})
\tag{2}\] The above is the circuit diagram and hamiltonian which weâ€™ll be using to understand the dyanmics of the field first using semiclassical analysis and then using quantum treatment.

title: Purcell Filter
text:
3 Semiclassical Analysis of Purcell Filter
Now by looking at the resonator field evolution (\(\hat{a}\)) and filter field evolution (\(\hat{b}\)) in the rotating frame at the drive frequency,\(e^{i \omega_d t}\) then the langevin equation in the semi-classical limit is given by \[
\dot{\alpha} = -i \Delta_{rd} \alpha - i G \beta - i g \epsilon_r
\] \[
\dot{\beta} = -i \Delta_{fd} \beta - i G^{*} \alpha - \frac{\kappa_f}{2} \beta
\]
